messageBody:
Hi Andrew,

> How generic is the book? Is it somewhat (or greatly) applicable to
> projects outside of Java?

Most of the automation tools described in the book -- Ant,
CruiseControl, Groovy, JUnit, Log4j, Jetty -- are Java based. I
mention NAnt and CruiseControl.NET as a way for readers in the .NET
environment to follow along as the tools are very similar.

I use Mac OS X, so the command-line examples use Unix syntax and the
book includes a few shell scripts. However, the Unix commands I use
(e.g. cd, mkdir, etc.) are easy to translate to Windows environments
and the Windows shell scripting language is powerful enough to handle
the duties of the Unix shell scripts I present.

Tools and operating systems aside, the automation concepts are relevant
to any software project. Indeed, I tried to use a mix of tools (you'll
even see some Ruby!) just to illustrate that the tools are simply a
means to an end. You'll get a flavor of that in the two sample
chapters:

http://www.pragmaticprogrammer.com/sk/auto/

You might also check out the book's companion web site:

http://pragmaticautomation.com

It picks up where the book ends. I post automation tips, tricks,
tools, and stories from the trenches of software projects. Feel free
to suggest content from your environment.

Thanks!

Regards,

Mike
